abstract.p: Survey released by Jupiter Media Metrix shows about 20 percent fewer people visited online trading sites on the Web in second quarter, and those who did spent about half as much time there; dropoff was most pronounced at brokerage firms like E*Trade Grou that have no branches, and among women and people with high incomes (S)

block.p: Many online stock traders found something else to do after technology stocks took a steep dive last spring, according to survey results released yesterday by Jupiter Media Metrix. About 20 percent fewer people visited online trading sites on the World Wide Web in the second quarter, and those who did spent about half as much time there, said Rob Sterling, a senior analyst at Jupiter. The dropoff was most pronounced at brokerage firms like the E-trade Group that have no branches, and among women and people with high incomes, he said. ''These people got scared after the market behaved poorly,'' Mr. Sterling said.
